20110118160632.000|20110118160635.000|TR0|ALI VELSHI, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS 
20110118160635.000|20110118160638.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT:  Well yes.  I think if you 
20110118160638.000|20110118160640.000|TR0|ask people, what is China's economy 
20110118160640.000|20110118160643.000|TR0|compared to the United States, is it good 
20110118160643.000|20110118160646.000|TR0|for the U.S. or bad for the U.S.?  I think 
20110118160646.000|20110118160649.000|TR0|you get a lot mixed views.  And the fact 
20110118160649.000|20110118160652.000|TR0|is it's both.
20110118160652.000|20110118160655.000|TR0|
20110118160655.000|20110118160657.000|TR0|Let me show you the bad and the good.  I'm 
20110118160657.000|20110118160700.000|TR0|going to start with the bad, because 
20110118160700.000|20110118160703.000|TR0|that's the stuff we hear about.
20110118160703.000|20110118160706.000|TR0|
20110118160706.000|20110118160709.000|TR0|COSTELLO:  Yes, kick that out of the way.
20110118160709.000|20110118160711.000|TR0|
20110118160711.000|20110118160714.000|TR0|VELSHI:  We hear about that all the time.
20110118160714.000|20110118160717.000|TR0|
20110118160717.000|20110118160720.000|TR0|The first one is Chinese currency.  It's 
20110118160720.000|20110118160723.000|TR0|called the Yuan.  And it is pegged to the 
20110118160723.000|20110118160725.000|TR0|U.S. dollar, so it doesn't float like most 
20110118160725.000|20110118160728.000|TR0|currencies do.
20110118160728.000|20110118160731.000|TR0|
20110118160731.000|20110118160734.000|TR0|As a result of not floating, a lot of 
20110118160734.000|20110118160737.000|TR0|experts say the Yuan is undervalued by 10 
20110118160737.000|20110118160740.000|TR0|percent to 40 percent.  Well, what does 
20110118160740.000|20110118160742.000|TR0|that do? Undervaluing makes Chinese 
20110118160742.000|20110118160745.000|TR0|manufactured goods cheaper than similar 
20110118160745.000|20110118160748.000|TR0|U.S. manufactured goods.
20110118160748.000|20110118160751.000|TR0|
20110118160751.000|20110118160754.000|TR0|It's one of the reasons.  There's another 
20110118160754.000|20110118160756.000|TR0|one I'm going to talk to you about in a 
20110118160756.000|20110118160759.000|TR0|second, but it makes Chinese good cheaper.
20110118160759.000|20110118160802.000|TR0|
20110118160802.000|20110118160805.000|TR0|The other one, of course, is that Chinese 
20110118160805.000|20110118160808.000|TR0|workers, factory workers, get paid a lot 
20110118160808.000|20110118160810.000|TR0|less than U.S. workers do.  Take a look at 
20110118160810.000|20110118160813.000|TR0|that.  They earn less than $1 a day on 
20110118160813.000|20110118160816.000|TR0|average.  So that hurts U.S. workers.
20110118160816.000|20110118160819.000|TR0|
20110118160819.000|20110118160822.000|TR0|Now, one of the other things is that in 
20110118160822.000|20110118160825.000|TR0|China, like in the U.S., when we're 
20110118160825.000|20110118160827.000|TR0|suffering from job loss, they lost far 
20110118160827.000|20110118160830.000|TR0|more jobs than we did as a result of the 
20110118160830.000|20110118160833.000|TR0|recession.  People stopped buying stuff, 
20110118160833.000|20110118160836.000|TR0|Chinese factories stopped operating.
20110118160836.000|20110118160839.000|TR0|
20110118160839.000|20110118160841.000|TR0|So they've got a buy China policy, too.  
20110118160841.000|20110118160844.000|TR0|They favor companies that build and make 
20110118160844.000|20110118160847.000|TR0|things in China.  So that is hurting the 
20110118160847.000|20110118160850.000|TR0|sale of American exports to China.
20110118160850.000|20110118160853.000|TR0|
20110118160853.000|20110118160855.000|TR0|And finally, China is the banker to the 
20110118160855.000|20110118160858.000|TR0|world.  They own $938 billion worth of 
20110118160858.000|20110118160901.000|TR0|U.S. debt.  But they also lent more money 
20110118160901.000|20110118160904.000|TR0|to developing countries than the World 
20110118160904.000|20110118160907.000|TR0|Bank did over the course of the last two 
20110118160907.000|20110118160910.000|TR0|years.
20110118160910.000|20110118160912.000|TR0|
20110118160912.000|20110118160915.000|TR0|That's the bad.  Let me show you the good.
20110118160915.000|20110118160918.000|TR0|
20110118160918.000|20110118160921.000|TR0|What's good about the relationship that we 
20110118160921.000|20110118160924.000|TR0|have with China?  Well, the first thing is 
20110118160924.000|20110118160926.000|TR0|that they are a growing economy.
20110118160926.000|20110118160929.000|TR0|
20110118160929.000|20110118160932.000|TR0|China grew 9.6 percent in 2010.  America 
20110118160932.000|20110118160935.000|TR0|grew 2.4 percent.
20110118160935.000|20110118160938.000|TR0|
20110118160938.000|20110118160941.000|TR0|Why is it good that they're growing so 
20110118160941.000|20110118160943.000|TR0|fast, Carol?  Because they have got a 
20110118160943.000|20110118160946.000|TR0|growing consumer base, they buy stuff, and 
20110118160946.000|20110118160949.000|TR0|possibly stuff that we can make.
20110118160949.000|20110118160952.000|TR0|
20110118160952.000|20110118160955.000|TR0|Here's another issue.  They like to buy 
20110118160955.000|20110118160957.000|TR0|Chinese, but the truth is, Chinese buys so 
20110118160957.000|20110118161000.000|TR0|much stuff, that they buy a lot of 
20110118161000.000|20110118161003.000|TR0|American, too. They are the third larger 
20110118161003.000|20110118161006.000|TR0|buyer of U.S.-made goods.  Canada is the 
20110118161006.000|20110118161009.000|TR0|first, Mexico is the second, China is the 
20110118161009.000|20110118161011.000|TR0|third, and China is growing.
20110118161011.000|20110118161014.000|TR0|
20110118161014.000|20110118161017.000|TR0|Exports to China, American exports to 
20110118161017.000|20110118161020.000|TR0|China -- while we constantly talk about 
20110118161020.000|20110118161023.000|TR0|the fact that we import from them more 
20110118161023.000|20110118161026.000|TR0|than we export, we export to them a lot 
20110118161026.000|20110118161028.000|TR0|more than we used to.  American exports to 
20110118161028.000|20110118161031.000|TR0|China have increased 12 times over the 
20110118161031.000|20110118161034.000|TR0|last 20 years.  In other words, we export 
20110118161034.000|20110118161037.000|TR0|12 times as much as we did 20 years ago. 
20110118161037.000|20110118161040.000|TR0|Let's talk about their labor force.  While 
20110118161040.000|20110118161042.000|TR0|they earn very little money, the labor 
20110118161042.000|20110118161045.000|TR0|force is tightening.  They have fewer 
20110118161045.000|20110118161048.000|TR0|workers, which means they're going to have 
20110118161048.000|20110118161051.000|TR0|to start to increase the amount that they 
20110118161051.000|20110118161054.000|TR0|pay.  That's going to help.
20110118161054.000|20110118161056.000|TR0|
20110118161056.000|20110118161059.000|TR0|And as they increase the amount they pay, 
20110118161059.000|20110118161102.000|TR0|that also means that there's a growing, 
20110118161102.000|20110118161105.000|TR0|growing consumer class in China ready to 
20110118161105.000|20110118161108.000|TR0|buy more goods. And that presents business 
20110118161108.000|20110118161111.000|TR0|opportunity for U.S. businesses.  Not just 
20110118161111.000|20110118161113.000|TR0|big ones, Carol, but small ones as well.
20110118161113.000|20110118161116.000|TR0|
20110118161116.000|20110118161119.000|TR0|So, like everything in life, there's good 
20110118161119.000|20110118161122.000|TR0|and there's bad.  At this point in our 
20110118161122.000|20110118161125.000|TR0|economy, it would be wise for all of us to 
20110118161125.000|20110118161127.000|TR0|be thinking about what the opportunities 
20110118161127.000|20110118161130.000|TR0|are in China.  And while we think of this 
20110118161130.000|20110118161133.000|TR0|as only being a big business thing, it's 
20110118161133.000|20110118161136.000|TR0|not.
20110118161136.000|20110118161139.000|TR0|
20110118161139.000|20110118161142.000|TR0|A hundred million business travelers will 
20110118161142.000|20110118161144.000|TR0|be leaving China within the next 10 years. 
20110118161144.000|20110118161147.000|TR0| They're going to come to America, so you 
20110118161147.000|20110118161150.000|TR0|have a motel, you have restaurants.  
20110118161150.000|20110118161153.000|TR0|There's a way to benefit from the Chinese.

20110118165646.000|20110118165648.000|TR0|are prepping kids for an increasingly

20110118165728.000|20110118165731.000|TR0|This school will get $30,000.
